title: Blinding lights: Universal Music's IPO takes centre stage
text:
One thing to start: Monday marked the S&P 500's worst day of trading since May as the liquidity crisis at the Chinese property developer Evergrande rocked global financial markets. Here's analysis from the FT's Instant Insight, Lex and Alphaville articles on the debacle.

Wall Street readies for Universal's headlining act

Vincent Bolloré isn't afraid to play the long game. 

Cases in point: the gruelling five-year battle for control of Lagardère, from which he emerged victorious just last week, or the 2005 boardroom coup at the PR group Havas that dragged on for almost a decade.

Now, as his sprawling media conglomerate Vivendi prepares to spin out 60 per cent of its Universal Music on Amsterdam's Euronext exchange, another one of Bolloré's long-running bets will be put to the test.

Eight years after Vivendi rejected an $8.5bn bid for Universal from Japan's SoftBank — an offer that priced the label up to $3bn higher than analysts' valuations — the plan to position the music group as its crown jewel appears to be paying off.

The prospectus gives Universal an indicative valuation of €33bn, but analysts believe it is worth as high as €54bn.

Wall Street's theory is simple: the explosive growth of audio streaming has flushed Universal and its rival music labels with billions of dollars in royalties. That income will only continue to increase as platforms, including Spotify and Apple Music, grow their subscribers by the millions.

New streaming frontiers, including the social video app TikTok and the online fitness group Peloton, which pay for the rights to use popular music, have added to the frenzy.

And thanks to some clever dealmaking, Universal is especially poised to cash in.

Taking after his ruthless dealmaker boss, Universal's Lucian Grainge orchestrated a bold takeover of the struggling record label EMI in 2012 that turned the industry's “Big Four” into the “Big Three”.

Suddenly, Universal had gained a sizeable edge over its remaining rivals Sony and Warner for control of the world's most sought-after music. 

The group's “irreplaceable” catalogue, as described by UBS, boasts The Beatles, Kendrick Lamar, Taylor Swift, Oliva Rodrigo and The Weeknd, whose hit “Blinding Lights” became the most streamed song on Spotify last year.

But even the best songs risk being overplayed. Almost half of Universal's music revenue comes from songs less than three years old, meaning it must stay vigilant in finding new talent. And despite Wall Street's all-in mentality, sceptics worry that valuations are at their peak. One of the key headwinds said to be facing the industry is artists striking out on their own rather than signing to a label. 

While the appetite for streaming may seem bottomless now, it's time to make “some magic in emerging markets”, as Grainge put it to Abel Tesfaye, aka The Weeknd, during an interview with the FT.

Established markets in Europe are already becoming saturated. Its joint venture with Tencent to stream its music in China is a start, but building its presence in Asia and other low to middle-income countries will be essential to Universal's longevity.

Greensill adds insult to injury

What's the only thing worse than facing billions of dollars in losses on investment products that were marketed as safe alternatives to money market funds?

Being charged extra for the privilege of propping up the very company that caused all the pain.

This is the perverse situation investors in Credit Suisse's now-infamous supply-chain finance funds have found themselves in after the collapse of Greensill Capital.

DD regulars will know that the Swiss bank shepherded some of its most valued clients into $10bn of investment funds linked to SoftBank-backed Greensill. While Credit Suisse marketed the funds as ultra-safe, the bank is now battling to recover billions of dollars on behalf of its aggrieved clients after the fund made high-risk loans to dubious and potentially fraudulent borrowers.

Credit Suisse recently told investors that it expects to rack up a bill as high as $145m this year alone. And it's charging this eye-watering amount to the funds rather than eating the cost itself.

Why the exorbitant sum? Well, partly because Credit Suisse is paying millions of dollars to keep the lights on at Greensill. While the group filed for administration and bankruptcy earlier this year, the Swiss bank fears that it won't be able to file crucial insurance claims on behalf of the funds if Greensill falls into liquidation.

Needless to say, investors are less than thrilled.  

“It drives me nuts,” one said. “They created a flawed structure in the first place. Then had zero governance and monitoring. And now it has blown up, they are taking no responsibility and letting the investors pay for everything.”

If that's not bad enough, Credit Suisse has privately warned investors that if the battle to recoup losses stretches into next year, substantial recovery costs would be payable again. 

Talk about adding insult to injury.

DD dines with the ‘king of Spacs'

It has been a while since DD readers heard from Chamath Palihapitiya, the tech investor who has a penchant for memorable television appearances on the business news channel CNBC.

Palihapitiya, a former Facebook executive, helped to turn the special purpose acquisition company into the hottest thing on Wall Street — until the controversial investment vehicles hit a wall with regulators and have struggled to maintain the same levels of investor enthusiasm.

He hasn't announced a blank-cheque deal since January, when his Social Capital Hedosophia Holdings Corp V announced a tie-up with the digital lender SoFi. A rumoured merger with the gym chain Equinox reportedly came and went.

Chamath-starved readers needn't wait any longer: DD's Miles Kruppa caught up with the “king of Spacs” himself during a sit-down lunch at Social Capital's Palo Alto headquarters.

Over a meal of poached chicken, Palihapitiya (who arrived maskless while hosting lunch at the office, purportedly because of concerns about Covid-19) expressed second thoughts on his recent “levered long” approach to investing.

“I may be in the midst of changing my mind,” he said of his trademark bullishness.

Some of the other highlights from the interview, conducted in late spring:

  • Though Palihapitiya declined to disclose the identity of the climate change company he supposedly funded with an unpopular sale of Virgin Galactic stock, he said it was “incredible and growing like a maniac”;

  • On the subject of MP Materials, a controversial rare earth mining company that received an investment from Palihapitiya, he said: “My big regret with MP is that I didn't buy the whole bloody company”;

  • Palihapitiya abdicated responsibility for the actions of his followers, insisting his CNBC appearances and Twitter posts were merely an “avenue of learning for those that want to take it”;

  • After angering colleagues and kicking investors out of Social Capital, Palihapitiya said he would reopen to outside capital “under the right circumstances”.

Job moves

  • Jacqueline Hunt, a member of Allianz's board of management in charge of Allianz Global Investors, Pimco and the group's US life insurance business, is in talks about an early departure, two people familiar with the matter told the FT. Her exit would come as the insurer grapples with regulatory investigations into potential misconduct by US-based fund managers. 

  • Bank of America has promoted senior investment bankers Will Addas, Gary Howe and Giorgio Cocini to run its global financial institutions investment banking group. Arif Vohra was appointed as chair of Europe, the Middle East, and Africa financial institutions investment banking.

  • UBS has appointed Oliver Gaunt and Abudy Taha, managing directors on its leveraged finance team, as co-heads of leveraged finance for Emea. They succeed Sarah Mackey, who was recently named as the bank's head of investor relations.

  • Credit Suisse has recruited industrials banker Yuri Shakhmin as a managing director for Emea from Rothschild.

  • New York-based hedge fund Element Capital has hired Gertjan Vlieghe, who until last month was a member of the Bank of England's rate-setting Monetary Policy Committee as its chief economist.

  • Sagar Sanghvi has left his role as chief financial officer of Instacart to join the venture capital group Accel as a partner, based in Palo Alto.
